facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 18 of 1955 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 18 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 1, 1954, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 322 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 1, 1954, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 322 of 1953, arising out of the

facts.text: Judgment and order dated November 20, 1953, of the West Bengal First Special Court at Alipore in Case No. 3 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated November 20, 1953, of the West Bengal First Special Court at Alipore in Case No. 3 of 1953.

facts.text: The High Court of Calcutta certified under Art. 134(1)(c) of the Constitution that the case was fit for appeal to this Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Calcutta certified under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution that the case before us was a fit one for appeal to this Court.

facts.text: The appellant was convicted under s. 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 and under s. 161 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was companyvicted under s. 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947  II of 1947 , hereinafter referred to as the Act, and under s. 161

facts.text: Special Judge sentenced the appellant under s. 161 to undergo rigorous imprisonment for three months and to pay a fine of Rs. 500, in default further rigorous imprisonment for one month.

anchor.surface_text: of the Indian Penal Code by a Special Judge who sentenced him under s. 161, to undergo rigorous imprisonment for three months and to pay a fine of Rs. 500

facts.text: No separate sentence was passed under s. 5(2) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: in default to suffer further rigorous imprisonment for one month. No separate sentence was passed under s. 5 2  of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant unsuccessfully appealed to the High Court against his conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: He unsuccessfully appealed to the High Court against his companyviction and sentence.

facts.text: On or about May 12, 1952, the appellant accepted Rs. 100 as illegal gratification from V. S. Doraiswamy.

anchor.surface_text: The charge framed against the appellant under s. 161 of the Indian Penal Code, in substance, stated that on or about May 12, 1952,he had accepted Rs. 100

facts.text: The gratification was as a motive or reward for doing an official act and showing favour to Doraiswamy in claim cases against Bengal Nagpur Railway, subsequently Eastern Railway.

anchor.surface_text: as a motive or reward for doing an official act and showing in the exercise of his official functions favour to Doraiswamy in seeing that a speedy and favourable

facts.text: Doraiswamy and the appellant met in 1950.

anchor.surface_text: They met in 1950.

facts.text: Rs. 10 was paid to the appellant in October, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Rs. 10 was paid to the appellant in October, 1951, and Rs. 15 in January, 1952,

facts.text: Rs. 15 paid in January, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: and Rs. 15 in January, 1952, as the result of the appellant asking Doraiswamy for some gratification

facts.text: Appellant was Assistant Supervisor of Claim Cases of the Bengal Nagpur Railway of the Vizianagram Section.

anchor.surface_text: for speedy and favourable disposal of his claim cases. The appellant was at that time Assistant Supervisor of Claim Cases of the Bengal Nagpur Railway

facts.text: On secret information, Deputy Superintendent of Police, Special Police Establishment at Puri directed Inspector G. N. Brahma to contact Doraiswamy.

anchor.surface_text: On some secret information, the Deputy Superintendent of Police, Special Police Establishment at Puri directed Inspector G. N. Brahma to companytact Doraiswamy

facts.text: Doraiswamy met Brahma and was asked to meet again at Calcutta on May 10, 1952, after filing complaint.

anchor.surface_text: Brahma met Doraiswamy and asked him to meet him again at 1001 Calcutta on May 10, 1952, after the latter had filed a companyplaint

facts.text: Permission obtained from Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta to investigate.

anchor.surface_text: Permission was obtained from the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta to investigate the case.

facts.text: Doraiswamy met appellant in Calcutta and settled to pay Rs.100 on May 12, 1952 at 6 p.m. at India Coffee House.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Doraiswamy met the appellant in Calcutta and it was settled that the former would pay the latter Rs. 100 on May 12, 1952, at 6 p. m.

facts.text: Marked ten-rupee currency notes given to Doraiswamy.

anchor.surface_text: Marked tenrupee currency numberes were given to Doraiswamy.

facts.text: Appellant and Doraiswamy met at India Coffee House; talk about expediting claim cases; list and bundle of marked notes put in appellant's left upper shirt pocket.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and Doraiswamy met at the India Coffee House as arranged. There was a talk between them about expediting the claim cases which were being dealt

facts.text: Inspectors H. K. Mukherjee, S. B. Mitra, G. N. Gosh and Brahma apprehended appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Inspectors H. K. Mukherjee and S. B. Mitra along with G. N. Gosh, an Assistant Director of Postal Ser- vices and Brahma came up to the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant produced the currency notes and list after accusation.

anchor.surface_text: He was accused by the police of having received 10 ten-rupee currency numberes as bribe from Doraiswamy and was asked to produce them.

facts.text: Numbers of currency notes tallied with those given to Doraiswamy.

anchor.surface_text: The number of the currency numberes were checked and found to tally with the previously numbered numbers of the currency numberes

facts.text: Both courts below found prosecution case proved; concurrent findings of fact not questioned.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the prosecution was found to have been proved by both the companyrts below and the appellant was companyvicted and sentenced as stated above.

facts.text: Appellant had power to deal finally with claims up to Rs. 75 and recommend higher to superior.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant as Assistant Supervisor of Claim Cases of the then Bengal Nagpur Railway  later the Eastern Railway  had the power to deal finally with claims

facts.text: Doraiswamy working on behalf of several persons with claims against Railway, Vizianagram Section.

anchor.surface_text: Doraiswamy was working on behalf of several persons who had made claims against the Railway. These cases were numerous.

facts.text: Sanction for prosecution given by Mr. Bokil, Chief Commercial Superintendent, Eastern Railway.

anchor.surface_text: Sanction for the prosecution of the appellant was sought from the Chief Commercial Superintendent Mr. Bokil, P.W. 5.

facts.text: Mr. Bokil was competent to grant sanction; no dispute.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that Mr. Bokil was companypetent to grant the sanction.

facts.text: Bokil went through relevant papers and was satisfied before sanctioning; sanction Ex.6.

anchor.surface_text: He had stated in his evidence that before according the sanction he went through all the relevant papers and was satisfied that in the interests

facts.text: Validity of sanction under s.6 of the Act was the only question raised.

anchor.surface_text: The only question canvassed before us was whether there had been a valid sanction given under s. 6 of the Act

facts.text: Supreme Court held sanction was valid.

issues.text: whether there had been a valid sanction given under s. 6 of the Act without which no court could take cognizance of the offences alleged to have been committed by the appellant

anchor.surface_text: The only question canvassed before us was whether there had been a valid sanction given under s. 6 of the Act without which no court could take cognizance of the offences alleged to have been committed by the appellant.

issues.text: whether the sanction accorded in this case was a valid sanction

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary therefore to decide whether the sanction accorded in this case was a valid sanction. The substance of the sanction has already been stated but in order that there may be no misunderstanding we quote the very words of the sanction itself

issues.text: the question whether or not there was a proper sanction in the case

anchor.surface_text: the learned Judges were of the opinion that the question whether or not there was a proper sanction in the case was a question serious enough to justify the granting of a certificate.

arguments.claim: Certain statements made by Mr. Bokil in cross-examination clearly showed that he had not applied his mind to the facts and circumstances of the case and the sanction accorded by him was not a valid one

anchor.surface_text: It was, however, urged before the Special Judge, as it was urged in the High Court, that certain statements made by Mr. Bokil in cross- examination clearly showed that he had not applied his mind to the facts and circumstances of the case and the sanction accorded by him was not a valid one.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tion had been accorded by Mr. Bokil. It was, however, urged before the Special Judge, as it was urged in the High Court, that certain statements made

arguments.court_reasoning: The Special Judge rejected this contention and was satisfied that Ex. 6 on the face of it disclosed a valid sanction for the prosecution of the appellant.

arguments.claim: Exhibit 6 clearly states that the appellant had demanded... and the evidence of Mr. Bokil... clearly establish that a valid sanction had been accorded by Mr. Bokil

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit 6 clearly states that the appellant had demanded on May 12, 1952, as bribe the sum of Rs. 100 from Doraiswamy and had accepted the sum as a motive or reward for speedy and favourable settlement of the claim cases, that Mr. Bokil had applied his mind to the facts and the circumstances of the case and was satisfied that in the interests of justice, the appellant should be put on his trial...

arguments.claim: The sanction Ex. 6 was prepared by the police and it was put before me by the personnel branch of my office. I did not call for any record... did not enquire about the position of those claim cases

anchor.surface_text: In cross- examination, however, he made the following statement This sanction Ex. 6 was prepared by the police and it was put before me by the personnel branch of my office. I did not call for any record in connection with this matter from my office. I did not call for the connected claim cases nor did I enquire about the position of those claim cases.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e to his acceptance of Rs. 100 from Doraiswamy on May 12,1952, in circumstances which, if established, would companystitute offences under s. 161, Ind

arguments.court_reasoning: Mr. Bokils statement does not prove that he merely put his signature on a readymade sanction presented by the police... before he accorded sanction he went through all the relevant papers.

arguments.claim: I can hardly imagine the duty of granting the proper sanction being properly discharged by merely putting ones signature on a ready-made sanction presented by the police

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that Mr. Bokils statement does not prove that he merely put his signature on a readymade sanction presented by the police. It is true that he did not himself dictate or draft the sanction, but Mr. Bokil has stated in the clearest terms, in his examination-in-chief, that before be accorded sanction he went through all the relevant papers.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: is sanction Ex. 6 was prepared by the police and it was put before me by the personnel branch of my office. I did number call for any record in compan

arguments.court_reasoning: There is no reason to distrust this statement of Mr. Bokil... It is inconceivable that an officer of the rank of Mr. Bokil would blindly sign a ready-made sanction prepared by the police.

arguments.claim: Reliance was placed on the case of Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King and other cases... that the sanction accorded was not a valid sanction

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed on the case of Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King 1  and other cases, to which it is unnecessary to refer, in support of the submission on behalf of the appellant that the sanction accorded was not a valid sanction.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the appellant by calling for the records of the companynected claim cases or other records in companynection with the matter from his office. The pap

arguments.court_reasoning: A careful reading... of Morarkas case satisfies us that the sanction accorded in this case in no way conflicts with the observations of their Lordships of the Judicial Committee. On the contrary, in our opinion, it is in keeping with them.

arguments.claim: The learned Judges of the High Court who heard the appeal were also satisfied that Mr. Bokil had, in fact, applied his mind to the facts and circumstances of the case

anchor.surface_text: The Special Judge rejected this contention... The learned Judges of the High Court who heard the appeal were also satisfied that Mr. Bokil had, in fact, applied his mind to the facts and circumstances of the case. Regarding the statements made by Mr. Bokil in cross- examination they were of the opinion that they did not show that he did not apply his mind to the facts of the case.

arguments.claim: It was not for Mr. Bokil to judge the truth of the allegations made against the appellant by calling for the records of the connected claim cases or other records... The papers which were placed before him apparently gave him the necessary material upon which he decided that it was necessary in the ends of justice to accord his sanction

anchor.surface_text: It was not for Mr. Bokil to judge the truth of the allegations made against the appellant by calling for the records of the connected claim cases or other records in connection with the matter from his office. The papers which were placed before him apparently gave him the necessary material upon which he decided that it was necessary in the ends of justice to accord his sanction.

arguments.claim: This sanction clearly states all the facts which concern the prosecution case alleged against the appellant... The sanction also clearly states that Mr. Bokil had applied his mind and was of the opinion that in the interests of justice the appellant should be prosecuted

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this sanction clearly states all the facts which concern the prosecution case alleged against the the appellant with reference to his acceptance of Rs. 100 from Doraiswamy on May 12,1952, in circumstances which, if established, would constitute offences under s. 161, Indian Penal Code and s. 5 2  of the Act.

arguments.claim: The order granting the certificate shows that the learned Judges who heard the application were of the opinion that the sanction accorded in this case was not a valid sanction

anchor.surface_text: An application was filed in the High Court under Art. 134 of the Constitution for the granting of a certificate that the case was a fit one for appeal to this Court. The order granting the certificate shows that the learned Judges who heard the application were of the opinion that the sanction accorded in this case was not a valid sanction.

arguments.court_reasoning: It is necessary therefore to decide whether the sanction accorded in this case was a valid sanction.

holdings.text: When the sanction itself and the evidence of Mr. Bokil are carefully scrutinized and read together there can be little doubt that the sanction accorded was a valid sanction.

anchor.surface_text: When the sanction itself and the evidence of Mr. Bokil are carefully scrutinized and read together there can be little doubt that the sanction accorded was a valid sanction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sanction document details facts of offence, Bokil reviewed relevant papers and applied mind before signing, cross-examination statements do not negate application of mind, complies with requirements from Gokulchand case.

holdings.text: this sanction clearly states all the facts which concern the prosecution case alleged against the appellant with reference to his acceptance of Rs. 100 from Doraiswamy on May 12,1952, in circumstances which, if established, would constitute offences under s. 161, Indian Penal Code and s. 5(2) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this sanction clearly states all the facts which concern the prosecution case alleged against the the appellant with reference to his acceptance of Rs. 100 from Doraiswamy on May 12,1952, in circumstances which, if established, would constitute offences under s. 161, Indian Penal Code and s. 5 2  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sanction specifies incident date, amount, parties, purpose as motive/reward, references specific sections, states authority's satisfaction after applying mind.

holdings.text: the sanction accorded in this case in no way conflicts with the observations of their Lordships of the Judicial Committee. On the contrary, in our opinion, it is in keeping with them.

anchor.surface_text: A careful reading... of Morarkas case satisfies us that the sanction accorded in this case in no way conflicts with the observations of their Lordships of the Judicial Committee. On the contrary, in our opinion, it is in keeping with them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analysis of Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King confirms current sanction meets standards for validity outlined by Privy Council.

holdings.text: It was not for Mr. Bokil to judge the truth of the allegations made against the appellant by calling for the records of the connected claim cases or other records in connection with the matter from his office.

anchor.surface_text: It was not for Mr. Bokil to judge the truth of the allegations made against the appellant by calling for the records of the connected claim cases or other records in connection with the matter from his office. The papers which were placed before him apparently gave him the necessary material upon which he decided that it was necessary in the ends of justice to accord his sanction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sanctioning authority's role is to apply mind to presented materials and determine if prosecution serves justice, not to verify truth via independent investigation.

holdings.text: Mr. Bokils statement does not prove that he merely put his signature on a readymade sanction presented by the police.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that Mr. Bokils statement does not prove that he merely put his signature on a readymade sanction presented by the police. It is true that he did not himself dictate or draft the sanction, but Mr. Bokil has stated in the clearest terms, in his examination-in-chief, that before be accorded sanction he went through all the relevant papers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Drafting by police/personnel acceptable if authority reviews relevant papers and applies mind; Bokil's chief exam testimony credible, no reason to distrust.
